docs.lead_paragraph: A coroner has concluded that the singer and songwriter Jay Bennett, a former member of the rock band Wilco, died of an overdose of a painkiller, The Associated Press reported. Mr. Bennett, who performed with Wilco beginning in 1994 and contributed to the band’s albums “Being There,” “Summerteeth” and “Yankee Hotel Foxtrot,” died on May 24 in Urbana, Ill., where he lived. The cause of death was initially unknown. Duane E. Northrup, the coroner of Champaign County, said that tests showed Mr. Bennett had died from an overdose of fentanyl, a drug prescribed to treat chronic pain, and that his death was being investigated as an accident. Shortly before his death, Mr. Bennett wrote on his MySpace page that he had severe pains in his hip and needed hip-replacement surgery but did not have proper health insurance.

headline.main: Results in Autopsy of Ex-Wilco Member

docs.lead_paragraph: This development bears watching, as the left wing of the Democratic Party keeps going after top lawmakers within its own realm. This time, it's the health care issue on which advocates for President Obama's agenda (and well beyond that) have begun eating their own.MoveOn has begun urging its sizable membership to hound Senator Dianne Feinstein, Democrat of California, criticizing her for cautionary remarks she made on CNN on Sunday about overhauling the health care system.

headline.main: MoveOn Hammers Feinstein on Health Care Remarks

docs.abstract: A leading Democratic senator takes heat for expressing reservations about the current viability of drafts, just drafts, of health care legislation.

docs.lead_paragraph: Snap and banter, cigarettes and Spock ears, reminders about who is president: Barack Obama's fourth press conference was the best in confrontational TV since the "Real Housewives of New Jersey" had their last supper. The conference even managed to generate controversy mid-stride, when Politico went live with a post questioning the issue of "coordinated questions" between Obama and a reporter (a ball snappily tossed from Politico to Drudge to Twitter, the Tinker to Evers to Chance of our era).

docs.lead_paragraph: At his fourth White House news conference, President Obama spoke more forcefully than before about the violence in Iran, pushed hard for his health care agenda and acknowledged the steep unemployment rates. Please feel free to comment in the section below.
